multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "infect" rule in the Basic SIR model describe?
choices: An infected agent recovering and becoming resistant.
An infected agent infecting another agent, changing their state from Susceptible (S) to Infected (I).
The initial state of the model with all agents being susceptible.
The rate at which susceptible agents become infected.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the "network dynamics" feature add to the SIR model?
choices: The ability for agents to move within a grid, influencing infection spread.
The introduction of a "desert" state where agents are not susceptible to infection.
The ability for agents to change their connections, potentially avoiding infection.
The ability for agents to recover from the infection at a variable rate.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the tree-like diagram on the left of the SIR feature model represent?
choices: The relationships between different model features and their possible combinations.
The types of agents present in the model and their attributes.
The order in which the model is executed, showing the sequence of rule applications.
The different states an agent can be in and the transitions between them.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the model merging process shown in Figure 4?
choices: It highlights the computational complexity of simulating larger, more feature-rich models.
It demonstrates how models with different features can be combined to create more complex and realistic simulations.
It emphasizes the importance of validating model results against real-world data.
It showcases the process of calibrating model parameters to achieve accurate predictions.
